Methods¶

Enrichment of histone marks¶

The number of MNase reads supporting the position of a nucleosome is a confounding variable for the number of histone reads overlapping the same nucleosome. This may be due to position-specific properties of the genome, such as chromatin compactness or GC content, that results in local under-sampling of both MNAse and MNase ChIP-seq fragments. This process may introduced spurious signals of histone enrichment as some region may appear highly enriched compared with –otherwise equal– under-sampled regions. A widely used correction method is to normalized the number of histone reads by the number of MNase reads. That’s, on any given nucleosome, \(j\), the number of histone reads, \(x_j\), is normalized as the ratio:

\[r_j = \frac{ x_j } { n_j }\]

where \(n_j\) is the number of MNase reads.

This method assumes that \(x_j\) is linearly dependent on \(n_j\). However, this may not be a accurate representation of their relation. In particular, is plausible to assume that the proportion of under-sampled genomic regions is more prevalent among nucleosomes with low values of \(n_j\) than among nucleosomes with large values of \(n_j\). Under this assumption, we hypothesized that the expected value of \(x_j\) should follow a rather saturation curve with respect to \(n_j\).

To take this effect into account, we normalized \(x_j\) as:

\[r_j = \frac{ x_j } { E(X|n_j)}\]

where, \(E(X|n_j)\) is the expected number of histone reads per nucleosome, \(X\), given \(n_j\) supporting MNase reads.

To test whether our normalization method is better than the classical one, we first check our hypothesis by computing \(E(X|n_j)\) for the observed range of \(n_j\) using all genomic nucleosomes (iNPs):

\[E(X|n_j) = \frac{1}{||J(n_j)||} \sum_{j \in J(n_j)} x_j\]

Here, \(J(n_j)\) is the subset of nucleosomes with \(n_j\) supporting MNase reads.

By compromising all genomic nucleosomes, \(E(X|n_j))\) is not only unbias towards any position-specific biological function, but also tailors 1 as a reference point for \(r_j\): values of \(r_j\) above and below 1 can be interpreted as enriched or depleted, respectively, of histone marks.

Additionally, since \(E(X|n_j)\) is directly proportional to the total number of reads per histone library, the ratios \(r_j\) are a metric already normalized by library size.

For each MNase ChIP-seq library, after removing outliers (read counts per nucleosome over 99% quantiles) \(E(X|n_j)\) resulted (Figures 1-4) in monotonic transformations of the number of MNase reads per nucleosome. Interestingly, \(E(X|n_j)\) saturates in the direction of the \(x\)-axis, meaning that as the number of supporting of MNase reads gets larger its confounding effect on histone reads gets attenuated. By taking into account this effect, \(E(X|n_j)\) improves the sensitivity of \(r_j\) compared to the widely used method of using \(n_j\) as denominator for \(r_j\). This difference is specially important among nucleosomes with large values of \(n_j\), where using \(n_j\) as denominator for \(r_j\) would otherwise over-amplifies the difference between their histone enrichment signals.

These results support our hypothesis, and therefore favor the use of \(E(X|n_j)\) over \(n_j\) as denominators for \(r_j\).

The linear relationship between \(n_j\) and \(x_j\) would only holds when the proportion of under-sampled nucleosomes remains constant with respect to \(n_j\). If this may be the case for a particular library, \(E(X|n_j)\) will be simply reduce to \(n_j\). Thus, \(E(X|n_j)\) can be interpreted as general alternative to \(n_j\) for cases when the proportion of under-sampled nucleosomes doesn’t remain constant with \(n_j\).
